metadata.description: Complete consolidated phoneme data from all 8 stages
completion_notes: This represents the complete Science of Reading phonics progression
All 8 stages cover Kindergarten through 3rd Grade
Systematic progression from basic sounds to advanced morphology
Research-based sequence following Ehri, NRP, and other authorities

articulation_data.development_notes: One of the earliest sounds acquired. Should be mastered by age 3.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Lips together, vocal cords on. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Use mirror work to show lip closure. Easy sound for modeling.
articulation_data.student_tips: Put your lips together and hum. Feel the vibration.

introduction_phase.mastery_criteria: 90% accuracy in isolation and CVC words

struggling_learners.additional_practice: Double practice time with multisensory supports

advanced_learners.acceleration: Move to blends and advanced patterns

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: Sam has a mat. I am Sam.
weekly_data_override.tips: Use mirror work. Show lip closure clearly.

articulation_data.development_notes: Complex fricative requiring precise tongue placement. Lisps are common until age 6.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Tongue near roof of mouth, air flows quietly. üó£Ô∏è Unvoiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Use feather or tissue to show airflow. Common to have lisps initially.
articulation_data.student_tips: Make the snake sound. Feel the air on your hand.

introduction_phase.mastery_criteria: 90% accuracy in isolation and CVC words

formative_assessments.criterion: Identifies /s/ in initial, medial, final positions

summative_assessment.transfer: Uses /s/ knowledge in new words and blends

struggling_learners.additional_practice: Focus on tongue placement with visual/tactile cues

cultural_considerations: Some languages have different sibilant systems

weekly_data_override.assessment: Daily quick check: /s/ sound production without lisp
weekly_data_override.tips: Use feather test for airflow. Watch for lisps.

articulation_data.development_notes: Short vowel, typically early developing. Foundation for vowel system.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Mouth open, tongue low and forward. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Use exaggerated mouth opening. Contrast with other vowels.
articulation_data.student_tips: Open your mouth wide like at the doctor. Say 'ahh'.

cultural_considerations: Some languages don't distinguish vowel length

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: I am at the mat. Sam is mad.
weekly_data_override.tips: Emphasize wide mouth opening. Use mirror work.

articulation_data.development_notes: Voiceless alveolar stop. May show some variability until age 4.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Tongue taps behind teeth. üó£Ô∏è Unvoiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show tongue tip placement. Practice stop and release.
articulation_data.student_tips: Tap your tongue behind your top teeth.

formative_assessments.criterion: Identifies /t/ in initial and final positions

cultural_considerations: May aspirate differently in some languages

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The mat is at the top. Sam sat.
weekly_data_override.tips: Practice tongue tapping. Show stop and release.

content_generation_meta.context_sentences: Include both initial and final positions

articulation_data.development_notes: Early developing nasal sound. Should be consistent by age 3.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Tongue tip behind teeth, air through nose. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show nasal airflow. Compare with /m/.
articulation_data.student_tips: Put your tongue tip up, air comes out your nose.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The man can nap. I am not mad.
weekly_data_override.tips: Show nasal airflow with mirror or tissue.

articulation_data.development_notes: Early bilabial stop. Usually acquired with /b/ and /m/.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Lips burst open. üó£Ô∏è Unvoiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show lip closure and release. No voice.
articulation_data.student_tips: Press your lips together, then pop them open.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: Pat has a map. I can tap the pan.
weekly_data_override.tips: Emphasize lip closure and release. Practice without voice.

content_generation_meta.context_sentences: Include both initial and final positions

articulation_data.development_notes: Short i vowel. Usually well-established by age 3.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Mouth slightly open, lips relaxed, tongue high-mid. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show tongue position higher than /a/. Spread lips slightly.
articulation_data.student_tips: Say 'ih' with your mouth almost closed.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: I sit in the pit. Pat has the tip.
weekly_data_override.tips: Contrast with /a/. Show tongue position differences.

articulation_data.development_notes: Voiced alveolar stop. Should be consistent by age 4.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Tongue taps behind teeth. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Compare with /t/. Show voice difference.
articulation_data.student_tips: Tap your tongue and turn on your voice.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: Dad is mad. I am sad.

articulation_data.development_notes: Fricative that develops gradually. Normal variation until age 6.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Teeth on lip, air flows. üó£Ô∏è Unvoiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show teeth on lip contact. Demonstrate airflow.
articulation_data.student_tips: Bite your bottom lip gently, blow air out.

struggling_learners.additional_practice: Extended fricative work with visual cues

cultural_considerations: /f/ may not exist in all languages

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The fat man has a fan. If I can fit.
weekly_data_override.tips: Show teeth on lip. Use feather for airflow.

articulation_data.development_notes: Short o vowel. May vary with dialect.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Mouth round, tongue low-back. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show lip rounding. Compare with /a/.
articulation_data.student_tips: Make your lips round like you're surprised.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The pot is on top. I can mop the dot.
weekly_data_override.tips: Emphasize lip rounding. Use mirror work.

articulation_data.development_notes: Liquid sound requiring complex tongue movement. May vary by position in word.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Tongue touches behind top teeth. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show tongue tip contact. Demonstrate lateral airflow.
articulation_data.student_tips: Touch your tongue tip behind your teeth.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: I sit on dad's lap. The lamp is lit.
weekly_data_override.tips: Show tongue tip contact. Practice sustained /l/.

articulation_data.development_notes: Simple fricative, usually early developing. May be omitted in connected speech.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Soft puff of air. üó£Ô∏è Unvoiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show gentle airflow. Like fogging a mirror.
articulation_data.student_tips: Breathe out gently like you're warming your hands.

struggling_learners.additional_practice: Extended airflow work with visual cues

cultural_considerations: /h/ may be omitted in some languages

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The hat is hot. I hit the ham.
weekly_data_override.tips: Show gentle airflow. Use mirror fogging.

articulation_data.development_notes: Early developing voiced stop. Typically emerges with /p/.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Lips burst open. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Compare with /p/. Show voice difference.
articulation_data.student_tips: Press your lips together, turn on your voice, then pop them open.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The bat is bad. I can bat the ball.

decodable_sentences: The pet is in the pen.

articulation_data.development_notes: Short e vowel. May show variation until age 4.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Mouth slightly open, tongue mid-high. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show position between /a/ and /i/. Mid vowel.
articulation_data.student_tips: Say 'eh' like you're confused.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: Let me pet the dog. I bet it is soft.
weekly_data_override.tips: Show vowel ladder position. Practice vowel substitution.

decodable_sentences: Put the mud in the hut.

articulation_data.development_notes: Short u vowel. Foundation for back vowel development.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Mouth relaxed, tongue mid-low central. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show relaxed mouth position. Often confused with /o/.
articulation_data.student_tips: Say 'uh' like you're thinking.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The sun is fun. Put mud in the hut.
weekly_data_override.tips: Complete vowel system. Practice all five vowels.

articulation_data.development_notes: Later developing sound. /r/ and /r/ blends often difficult.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Tongue tip up, sides touch molars. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: This sound develops later. Focus on approximations initially.
articulation_data.student_tips: Make your tongue into a cup shape. Say 'errr' like a growling dog.

introduction_phase.mastery_criteria: 85% accuracy in isolation and simple words

decodable_sentences: The big dog got a bag.

articulation_data.development_notes: Back sound that may be fronted to /d/ in younger children.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Back of tongue touches soft palate. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Contrast with /k/ using voice on/off. Watch for fronting.
articulation_data.student_tips: Make a gulping sound. Feel your voice box vibrate.

struggling_learners.additional_practice: Extra voicing practice with tactile cues

articulation_data.development_notes: May be fronted to /t/ in younger children.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Back of tongue touches soft palate. üó£Ô∏è Voiceless
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Introduce c/k spelling rules. Watch for fronting.
articulation_data.student_tips: Make a coughing sound without your voice.

introduction_phase.mastery_criteria: 85% accuracy with c and k spellings

struggling_learners.additional_practice: Focus on one spelling at a time

english_learners.practice_emphasis: C before a,o,u; k before e,i

articulation_data.development_notes: Complex sound combining stop and fricative elements.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Tongue tip down, blade up. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Break down into /d/ + /zh/ if needed. Use jumping motion.
articulation_data.student_tips: Start with /d/ then slide to /zh/. Like saying 'judge'.

articulation_data.development_notes: Later developing. Often devoiced to /f/.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Upper teeth on lower lip. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Emphasize voicing. Use tactile cues on throat.
articulation_data.student_tips: Like /f/ but turn your voice on. Feel the buzzing.

articulation_data.development_notes: Early developing sound. May be omitted in clusters.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Round lips like whistling. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Emphasize lip rounding. Use mirror for visual feedback.
articulation_data.student_tips: Make your lips round like saying 'oo' then open them.

introduction_phase.mastery_criteria: 90% accuracy in isolation and initial position

activities: wa, we, wi, wo, wu practice

decodable_sentences: My cat is yet to come.

articulation_data.development_notes: May be omitted in clusters. Sometimes substituted with /l/.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Tongue high and forward. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show tongue position. Contrast with /w/ lip rounding.
articulation_data.student_tips: Smile and say 'ee' then open to make /y/.

activities: ya, ye, yi, yo, yu practice

summative_assessment.transfer: Distinguishes consonant y from vowel y

articulation_data.development_notes: Often devoiced to /s/. Later developing sound.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Tongue tip behind teeth. üó£Ô∏è Voiced buzzing
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Emphasize voicing. Use bee buzzing analogy.
articulation_data.student_tips: Make a buzzing bee sound. Feel your voice box vibrate.

decodable_sentences: The fox is in the box.

articulation_data.development_notes: Two-sound combination. May simplify to single sound.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Say /k/ then /s/ quickly. üó£Ô∏è Voiceless
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Break into /k/ + /s/ if needed. Practice blending speed.
articulation_data.student_tips: Say 'k-s' fast together. Like 'ks' in 'books'.

articulation_data.development_notes: Blend of /k/ and /w/. Q always followed by u in English.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Say /k/ then quickly round lips for /w/. üó£Ô∏è Mixed voicing
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Emphasize qu partnership. Never q alone.
articulation_data.student_tips: Say 'k' then quickly say 'w'. Q and U are best friends!

articulation_data.development_notes: Each sound maintains identity. Common reduction in younger children.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Say each sound clearly but close together. üó£Ô∏è Keep both sounds
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Start with 2-sound blends. Maintain each sound clearly.
articulation_data.student_tips: Say both sounds but push them close together.

struggling_learners.additional_practice: One blend family at a time

decodable_sentences: The fish is in the dish.

articulation_data.development_notes: Two letters, one sound concept. May substitute with /s/.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Round lips, tongue up behind teeth. üó£Ô∏è Voiceless
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Emphasize lip rounding. Show tongue position behind teeth.
articulation_data.student_tips: Make a quiet sound like 'shh' to be quiet.

articulation_data.development_notes: Affricate = stop + fricative. Two letters, one sound.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Tongue tip up, quick release. üó£Ô∏è Voiceless
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show affricate nature. Contrast with /j/ voicing.
articulation_data.student_tips: Start with /t/ then add /sh/ quickly. Like a sneeze!

summative_assessment.transfer: Applies ch patterns in new words

articulation_data.development_notes: Later developing. Tongue between teeth visible.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Tongue tip between teeth, blow air. üó£Ô∏è Voiceless
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show tongue placement. Mirror work helpful.
articulation_data.student_tips: Stick your tongue out a little and blow air gently.

articulation_data.development_notes: Later developing. Voiced version of /th/.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Tongue between teeth, voice on. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Contrast with voiceless /th/. Use high-frequency words.
articulation_data.student_tips: Same as /th/ but turn your voice on. Feel the buzzing.

articulation_data.development_notes: Combination of /h/ + /w/. Often simplified to /w/.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Blow air then round lips for /w/. üó£Ô∏è Voiceless start
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Many dialects merge with /w/. Teach for spelling.
articulation_data.student_tips: Blow a little air then say /w/. Like a quiet whistle then /w/.

articulation_data.development_notes: Back nasal sound. Two letters, one sound.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Back of tongue up, air through nose. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show back tongue position. Emphasize nasal airflow.
articulation_data.student_tips: Hum with the back of your tongue touching the roof of your mouth.

articulation_data.development_notes: Same sound as /k/, different spelling pattern.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Back of tongue touches soft palate. üó£Ô∏è Voiceless
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Focus on spelling rule: ck after short vowels.
articulation_data.student_tips: After a short vowel, use 'ck' instead of just 'k'.

articulation_data.development_notes: Same sound as /f/, different spelling pattern.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Upper teeth on lower lip, blow air. üó£Ô∏è Voiceless
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Emphasize ph = /f/ equivalence. Greek origin words.
articulation_data.student_tips: Ph makes the same sound as f. It's like a secret code!

articulation_data.development_notes: Long vowel version of /a/. 'Says its name'.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Open mouth, say letter name 'A'. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Emphasize silent e makes vowel say its name.
articulation_data.student_tips: The silent e makes the a say 'A' like the letter name!

articulation_data.development_notes: Long vowel version of /i/. 'Says its name'.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Smile wide, say letter name 'I'. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Connect to short i. Show silent e effect.
articulation_data.student_tips: The silent e makes the i say 'I' like the letter name!

decodable_sentences: The rope is on the boat.

articulation_data.development_notes: Long vowel version of /o/. 'Says its name'.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Round lips, say letter name 'O'. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Emphasize lip rounding. Connect to short o.
articulation_data.student_tips: The silent e makes the o say 'O' like the letter name!

articulation_data.development_notes: Can be /≈´/ (yoo) or /oÕûo/ (oo). Complex pattern.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Round lips tightly, say 'U' or 'OO'. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Introduce both sounds. Context dependent.
articulation_data.student_tips: U_e can say 'U' (cute) or 'OO' (tune). Listen for both!

articulation_data.development_notes: Long vowel version of /e/. Less common VCe pattern.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Slight smile, say letter name 'E'. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Less frequent than other VCe patterns. Focus on recognition.
articulation_data.student_tips: The silent e makes the e say 'E' like the letter name!

decodable_sentences: I like to bake at home.

articulation_data.development_notes: Integration of complete VCe system. Critical for reading development.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Each vowel maintains distinct position. üó£Ô∏è All voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Emphasize silent e rule across all vowels. Systematic practice.
articulation_data.student_tips: Silent e is magic for ALL vowels! It makes them say their names.

decodable_sentences: We need to feed the sheep.

articulation_data.development_notes: Long e vowel team. Two letters working together.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Slight smile, long 'E' sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Emphasize two letters, one sound. Start with ee, then ea.
articulation_data.student_tips: When two e's are together, they say 'E'!

decodable_sentences: I like to play in the rain.

articulation_data.development_notes: Long a vowel team. Position-dependent spelling.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Open mouth, long 'A' sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Teach position rule: ai in middle, ay at end.
articulation_data.student_tips: AI stays in the middle, AY likes the end!

decodable_sentences: The boat is on the road.

articulation_data.development_notes: Long o vowel team. Multiple spellings possible.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Round lips, long 'O' sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Emphasize lip rounding. Show multiple spellings.
articulation_data.student_tips: Round your lips and say a long 'O' sound!

decodable_sentences: I turn to see the fern.

articulation_data.development_notes: R-controlled vowel. R changes vowel sound completely.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Vowel + r blend together. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Introduce 'bossy r' concept. R controls the vowel.
articulation_data.student_tips: When R follows a vowel, it's bossy and changes the sound!

decodable_sentences: The car is in the park.

articulation_data.development_notes: R-controlled vowel. More consistent than er/ir/ur.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Open mouth, add /r/ sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Usually more consistent than other r-controlled vowels.
articulation_data.student_tips: AR says 'ar' like in 'car'. The R is still bossy!

articulation_data.development_notes: R-controlled vowel with multiple spellings.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Round lips, add /r/ sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show multiple spellings. Focus on common patterns.
articulation_data.student_tips: OR has many ways to spell it, but sounds the same!

struggling_learners.additional_practice: Focus on most common or spellings

articulation_data.development_notes: Long oo sound. Multiple spelling patterns.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Round lips tightly, long 'OO' sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Emphasize tight lip rounding. Show multiple spellings.
articulation_data.student_tips: Make your lips very round like a tunnel for a long 'OO'!

decodable_sentences: I play in the rain near the tree.

articulation_data.development_notes: Integration of complete vowel team system.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Each pattern maintains distinct position. üó£Ô∏è All voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Systematic review of all patterns. Focus on distinctions.
articulation_data.student_tips: Remember: vowel teams work together to make new sounds!

decodable_sentences: The mouse ran out of the house.

articulation_data.development_notes: Diphthong - two vowel sounds that glide together.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Start with 'ah', glide to 'oo'. üó£Ô∏è Voiced glide
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show mouth movement. Emphasize gliding motion.
articulation_data.student_tips: Your mouth moves from 'ah' to 'oo' - like saying 'ouch'!

decodable_sentences: I found a coin in the soil.

articulation_data.development_notes: Diphthong - glides from /o/ to /i/.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Start with 'aw', glide to 'ee'. üó£Ô∏è Voiced glide
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show clear position rule: oi in middle, oy at end.
articulation_data.student_tips: OI stays in the middle, OY likes the end - like AI and AY!

articulation_data.development_notes: Low back vowel with multiple spelling patterns.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Open mouth wide, back tongue position. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show multiple spellings. Focus on common patterns first.
articulation_data.student_tips: Open your mouth wide and say 'aw' like you hurt yourself!

articulation_data.development_notes: Shorter version of long oo. Context dependent.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Less rounded than long oo, shorter sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Contrast with long oo. Context often determines pronunciation.
articulation_data.student_tips: This oo is shorter - like in 'book' not 'moon'!

articulation_data.development_notes: Can be /yoo/ (few) or /oo/ (grew). Context dependent.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Either /y/ + /oo/ or just /oo/. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Introduce both sounds. Context often determines choice.
articulation_data.student_tips: EW can say 'yoo' (new) or 'oo' (grew) - listen for both!

decodable_sentences: I believe the field has eight pieces.

articulation_data.development_notes: Complex pattern with rules and exceptions.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Either long 'E' or long 'I' sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Introduce 'i before e except after c' rule with exceptions.
articulation_data.student_tips: I before E except after C - but watch for exceptions!

articulation_data.development_notes: Can be /yoo/ (rescue) or /oo/ (blue). Context dependent.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Either /y/ + /oo/ or just /oo/. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Similar to ew pattern. Context determines sound choice.
articulation_data.student_tips: UE can say 'yoo' (rescue) or 'oo' (blue) - try both!

decodable_sentences: The boy could see eight new books in the field.
I caught the blue mouse in the house.

articulation_data.development_notes: Integration of complex vowel pattern system.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Flexible vowel positioning. üó£Ô∏è All voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Systematic review emphasizing flexible reading strategies.
articulation_data.student_tips: Use all your vowel knowledge - try different sounds if needed!

decodable_sentences: The bright light shines at night.
I can see the sight with my eye.

articulation_data.development_notes: Long i in complex three-letter pattern.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Smile wide, long 'I' sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: IGH is always /ƒ´/. Very consistent pattern.
articulation_data.student_tips: IGH always says long 'I' - it's a team of three letters!

articulation_data.development_notes: Long a in complex four-letter pattern.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Open mouth, long 'A' sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: EIGH always says /ƒÅ/. Connect to number eight.
articulation_data.student_tips: EIGH says long 'A' - remember the word 'eight'!

decodable_sentences: The city has a nice dance scene.
I see ice in the circle.

articulation_data.development_notes: C says /s/ before e, i, y. Rule-based pattern.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Tongue tip behind teeth, /s/ sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiceless
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Teach soft c rule: c = /s/ before e, i, y.
articulation_data.student_tips: C is soft like /s/ before E, I, and Y!

decodable_sentences: A gentle giraffe lives by the bridge.

articulation_data.development_notes: G says /j/ before e, i, y. Parallel to soft c.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Tongue tip down, /j/ sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Teach soft g rule: g = /j/ before e, i, y.
articulation_data.student_tips: G is soft like /j/ before E, I, and Y - just like soft C!

formative_assessments.criterion: Connects soft c and g rules

decodable_sentences: I watch the match in the kitchen.

articulation_data.development_notes: Three-letter spelling after short vowels.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Same as /ch/ sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiceless
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: TCH after short vowels, CH after long vowels/consonants.
articulation_data.student_tips: After short vowels, use TCH for the /ch/ sound!

decodable_sentences: The judge stands on the bridge edge.
A large cage is on the stage.

articulation_data.development_notes: Three-letter spelling after short vowels, parallel to tch.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Same as /j/ sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: DGE after short vowels, GE after long vowels/consonants.
articulation_data.student_tips: After short vowels, use DGE for the /j/ sound - like TCH!

decodable_sentences: I walk and talk in the calm cold.
Half the salt helps the calf.

articulation_data.development_notes: L often silent in certain consonant clusters.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Don't pronounce the L in these patterns. üó£Ô∏è Various
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: L is often silent before k, m, f in common words.
articulation_data.student_tips: In some words, L is silent - you don't say it!

summative_assessment.transfer: Recognizes silent l in new words

decodable_sentences: Eight giant lights catch the calm city bridge.
I walk right to weigh the match.

articulation_data.development_notes: Integration of advanced phonics patterns and rules.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Apply all pattern knowledge flexibly. üó£Ô∏è Mixed
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Systematic review emphasizing rule application and exceptions.
articulation_data.student_tips: Use all your advanced pattern knowledge - remember the rules!

decodable_sentences: I know the knight has a knife.
The gnome can design a sign.

articulation_data.development_notes: Silent consonants from historical spellings. Only /n/ pronounced.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Just say /n/, ignore the silent letter. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: K and G are silent in these patterns. Historical spelling.
articulation_data.student_tips: The K in KN and G in GN are silent - just say /n/!

summative_assessment.transfer: Recognizes silent patterns in new words

articulation_data.development_notes: Silent W before R. Only /r/ pronounced.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÖ Just say /r/, ignore the silent W. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: W is silent before R in these patterns.
articulation_data.student_tips: The W in WR is silent - just say /r/!

decodable_sentences: The lamb has a calm thumb.
I climb to the palm tree.

articulation_data.development_notes: Silent B after M. Only /m/ pronounced.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Just say /m/, ignore the silent B. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: B is silent after M in word endings.
articulation_data.student_tips: The B after M is silent - just say /m/!

decodable_sentences: The captain has a pencil about the circus.
A famous lesson was taken in the mansion.

articulation_data.development_notes: Unstressed vowel sound. Most common sound in English.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Relaxed, unstressed 'uh' sound. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Focus on unstressed syllables in multisyllabic words.
articulation_data.student_tips: In unstressed syllables, vowels often say 'uh' (schwa)!

decodable_sentences: I am unhappy and unable to unlock it.
It is unfair and unsafe to undo that.

articulation_data.development_notes: Meaningful prefix meaning 'not' or 'opposite of'.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ /un/ at word beginning changes meaning. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Focus on meaning: un- = not or opposite of.
articulation_data.student_tips: UN- at the beginning means 'not' or 'opposite'!

summative_assessment.transfer: Applies un- understanding to new words

decodable_sentences: I am running and jumping while reading.
She is writing and singing while walking.

articulation_data.development_notes: Verb suffix indicating ongoing action.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ /ing/ at word end shows action happening. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Connect to ongoing action. Base word + ing.
articulation_data.student_tips: -ING at the end means the action is happening now!

decodable_sentences: She wanted and needed help when it started.

articulation_data.development_notes: Past tense suffix with three pronunciations: /t/, /d/, /ed/.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Three sounds: /t/, /d/, or /ed/. üó£Ô∏è Depends on base word
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Teach three -ed sounds based on final sound of base word.
articulation_data.student_tips: -ED can say /t/, /d/, or /ed/ - listen to the base word ending!

struggling_learners.additional_practice: Focus on one -ed sound at a time

decodable_sentences: The butterfly sits in the sunshine.
My grandmother plays baseball on the playground.

articulation_data.development_notes: Two words combined to make new meaning.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Two words put together make new meaning. üó£Ô∏è Mixed
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show how two words combine to create new meaning.
articulation_data.student_tips: Compound words are two words stuck together to make a new word!

decodable_sentences: The tiger happens to be important.
A fantastic robot sits in the wagon.

articulation_data.development_notes: Systematic approach to dividing multisyllabic words.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Break words into manageable parts. üó£Ô∏è Mixed
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Teach systematic syllable division patterns.
articulation_data.student_tips: Break long words into syllables to read them easier!

decodable_sentences: Unfortunately, the extraordinary investigation requires international communication.
Understanding the transformation shows great responsibility.

articulation_data.development_notes: Integration and mastery of complete English phonics system.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Apply all learned patterns flexibly. üó£Ô∏è Mixed
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Culminating integration of all phonics knowledge and strategies.
articulation_data.student_tips: Use everything you've learned - you're a phonics expert now!
